text: Hey there and welcome back for some more
Unreal animation training. I'm Sir Wade
and we're going to take a look at the
AOM animation sample project one last
time for a few more videos. This is the
fourth series in case you're watching
all of them and we're going to dive into
the technical animation tools this time
around. In this particular video, we're
going to start off with the new motion
trails that were introduced in Unreal
Engine 5.6, which are very powerful. And
in case you're just joining us, this is
technically the fourth set of videos in
this series. And so if you're looking
for something to kind of ease in, catch
up on some of the others and come on
back. But here we are in the sample
project. I am in shot 50, which is this
awesome shot where he breaks through the
door. We've got Gamma jumping through
the little gap that gets created and
Beta is forcing open the doors. We're
going to cover the constraints and other
stuff in some later videos, but for now,
let's focus on the motion trails using
Gamma. So here he comes, hopping through
the little uh gap in the door. Let's go
ahead and leave our camera behind and we
can see him pop on through. Wee. There
he goes. So, I'm going to come in here
and grab the body control on Gamma. Now,
to activate motion trails, it's actually
very straightforward. Up at the top of
our UI, we have this little bouncing
ball icon here. If we click on this, it
will automatically create a motion trail
for the selected object. It's a little
bit thin, but it is there. If I hide my
uh control curves, you can see the
little purple line hopefully. Now, just
to make sure we can see this, I'm going
to go up to the top little menu here.
Twirl this down. I'm going to go to
advanced, and I'm going to change the
trail thickness to something like two.
Now, you won't actually see the change
until you sort of refresh this by
collapsing the menu, and then it'll pop
up. So, it's not a dynamic slider. Uh,
right off the bat, I'm going to go back
in here and change the trail style from
default, which is just a solid color.
And actually, you know what I should do
is I should also turn on show marks. So
you can see the individual key frame
spots of where the frames are. And we
can also go back in here and we can
adjust the size of things like marks. I
can maybe switch this to like 10. Maybe
make the key size, I don't know, five.
Hit enter. And then when I go and
refresh this little menu, the things all
changed. So now we have this square key
at the end, little marks throughout. But
what I want to do is I want to change in
the drop down the trail style from
default to dashed will show you an
actual spacing layout of our animation.
So now when we hit play, we can actually
see the uh you know the spacing as he
jumps through the through the little gap
here. Or we can switch it to some other
more interesting modes. There's dash.
There's also time which is kind of what
you expect for before and after. before
and after of wherever the character is
and versus where he's going. But the new
one I really like is heat map. Heat map
is really interesting. The heat map mode
shows you where the character is moving
the fastest or the slowest. So the
hotter the heat map, so this red section
for example, the further the distance,
the bigger the spacing. Anywhere where
it's green is where the character is
moving at their slowest. So we have some
hang time up the top here, and that is
the slow part. speeds up with gravity. A
little bit slower there, a little bit
faster there. And so the heat map is a
really interesting way to look where you
can find speed problems. Now, if I go
back to my camera view, we can see what
this looks like. So, here is the
character's path through space.
And you'll notice that as we kind of
move around with our camera shake, the
trail through space is actually in world
space. It's just a a plotted out path of
where the character is going to go just
in 3D space. But one of the big reasons
that we like motion trails is sometimes
being able to look at it from the
specific camera's perspective. Uh having
it in camera space can be very helpful.
So what we can do to switch that is we
can actually take this motion trail that
we have selected and again just to get
this there I selected one control and I
hit this little button. If I want to
just click this button again that'll
turn it off. I can turn it back on and
that's a a quick and easy way to get in
and out of the motion trail. But if I
want to change the way the motion trail
operates, I can twirl this down. I can
go to the top stack body itself and
that's the specific pinned trail. You
can have multiple things pinned. We'll
cover that in a second. But I can
actually change the space that this is
in. So if I hit this little um uh
checkbox, it now asks, hey, what object
are we wanting to sort of put it in the
space of? So I'll pick my camera. and
it'll say what part of the camera I want
the camera component. If I do that now,
what will happen is that this motion
trail is more or less going to be
parented to the camera. And so if I move
around, you'll see that the entire
motion trail is kind of shifting in a
perspective view, right? The whole
thing's moving as if the character were
sliding. What's happening here is it's
actually now attached to the camera.
It's been stabilized and normalized in
camera space. So now I can actually see
where the character is going to be and
what their arc is going to be from the
camera's perspective considering the
camera shake and other camera animation
I have in the shot. So that can be
really really helpful depending on what
you're doing to be able to lock the
motion trail into camera space so
easily. And if we say you know what I
don't want that anymore I want to go
back to just world space motion trails
to see if I'm having another problem. I
can go back to the body control and I
can just say you know what turn that
space off. And now you can see that it
recalculates and it's moving again in
world space. So if I leave the camera
view, that motion trail is stable and it
just represents the 3D position. Now to
go a little bit deeper, if I want to get
this thing off, I can just deselect it
and that just turns it off. But let's
say I want to look at a body control,
maybe one of the tail controls, and let
me see if there's a good head control
here. Maybe just grab the uh the neck
start. And that's going to be kind of
the base of the skull here. And then
maybe I'll grab like the jaw control,
which is this little one right under the
jaw. That's a good one. We can kind of
track where the nose is going to be,
more or less. But now it might behave a
little differently than you expect. If I
just click this button, it won't
actually just make motion controls for
all these objects because I already had
a selection. I was already using the
body. And so it basically just assumes,
oh, hey, you know, we just wanted to
reenable what we had. Now I can unpin
whatever I have already, you know, being
shown and displayed with the motion
trail, or I can say pin selected, which
I'll go ahead and do. If I say pin
selected, it will add any selected
objects and create motion trails for
those as well. And so here is where I
might want to go in and change the trail
style from heat map to dashed. Or maybe
this is a good example of where you
might want to use something like time
because with so many you know lines and
curves it can be a little bit tricky to
know where we are in time. So now I can
see ah the blue section has passed the
red section is where we are and it's a
little bit easier to differentiate sort
of where these things are are located.
But then also you might want to adjust
you know the the size of these things.
So if the trail thickness is a little
bit too much now I might bring it down
to 1.2. Hit enter. close that little
menu and that'll shrink them all a
little bit which helps. But anyways,
that's what pinning does. I'll click
this to just turn everything off. But
you can mouse over and you can see some
of these hotkeys. You can altclick to
remove a selected object from the pin
list. You can, you know, basically just
add and subtract stuff from from what's
all being displayed. You can also switch
this to show trails on selection. And
then if I turn this on now, what it'll
do is it'll use my selection. So, if I
grab a neck control or if I grab one of
the the ear controls or something, um,
it's going to add things based on my
selection, which can be handy, but also
if I grab a whole bunch of things at
once, it can be a little bit
overwhelming. I think the default is 10
things here. Yeah, max number of pinned.
It's set to 10 by default. It doesn't
want to pin more than 10 things at once.
So, you can up that, reduce that,
whatever you want to do. Just different
modes. So you can have selection based
trails, you can have pinned trails that
are just there all the time. I can unpin
the trails so that there's nothing
that's always there. Um, but I can grab
individual controls and I can, for
example, shiftclick and that will add it
to the pin list. And so now I've got a
head control here. And you can see
inside there is my neck pinned trail
here. And then there's also an offset
button. And so if you hit offset, what
that's going to allow you to do is get
the uh manipulator here. You can see
that it's turned red. I'm kind of in
this this preview mode. And I'm allowed
to now move this. It's defaulted to the
center point, I believe, of the actual
joint that that control is responsible
for. But if you know what I want this to
be offset, it's it is the neck, but I
want it to show me from the top of the
neck. I can move this to the top of the
neck, and it's going to offset sort of
where it calculates that path from. So,
it's still using the same bone or the
same control or whatever, but now it's
just offset from where it was before.
And so, these are some of the options
that you are given to adjust how these
motion trails are going to operate. You
can also change the specific amount of
frames if you don't want to have, you
know, the whole shot visible all at
once. And so, you can change it so that
you only see, you know, 10 frames in
either direction or whatever. So, it
kind of shows up, goes away. You can see
it here. And so, that's the new motion
trails in a nutshell. It is a very very
handy new rewrite of the tools that
gives you a lot of flexibility. And so
feel free to explore that. Change the
colors, the sizes, things like that. And
you know, enjoy visualizing your shot,
adjusting your arcs, and ensuring that
the motion looks the way you want from
specific camera angles or just in world
space and so on it.
